Know that this is a great day, through which Allah has magnified Islam and has specifically favored the Muslims. Allah, the Exalted, says: "When the call is proclaimed for the prayer on the day of Friday [al-Jumu'ah], hasten earnestly to the remembrance of Allah and leave off business." Thus, He prohibited preoccupation with the affairs of the world [al-dunya] and with everything that diverts from hastening to the Friday prayer. And He, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, has made the Friday prayer obligatory upon you on this day of mine, in this place of mine." And He, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever abandons the Friday prayer three times without an excuse, Allah will seal his heart [qalb]." In another wording: "He has indeed cast Islam behind his back." And in the report: "The people of the two scriptures were given Friday, but they differed concerning it, so they were turned away from it, and Allah, the Exalted, guided us to it and postponed it for this nation, and made it a festival for them. Thus, they are the foremost people to it, and the people of the two scriptures follow them." And in the hadith of Anas from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he said: "Jibril, upon him be peace, came to me with a white mirror in his hand and said: 'This is Friday. Your Lord has made it obligatory upon you so that it may be a festival for you and for your nation after you.' I said: 'What is for us in it?' He said: 'For you in it is a good hour. Whoever supplicates in it for a good thing, it is apportioned for him; Allah, the Glorified, grants it to him. Or if it is not apportioned for him, it is stored for him what is greater than it. Or whoever seeks refuge from an evil decreed for him, Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, grants him refuge from what is greater than it. And it is the master of days for us, and we call it in the Hereafter [al-akhirah] the Day of Increase.' I said: 'Why?' He said: 'Indeed, your Lord, the Mighty and Majestic, has taken in Paradise a spacious valley of white musk. When Friday comes, He, the Exalted, descends from the Highest Place to His Throne, and He manifests Himself to them until they look upon His Noble Face.'" And He, peace be upon him, said: "The best day upon which the sun has risen is Friday. On it, Adam, upon him be peace, was created; on it, he was admitted to Paradise; on it, he was sent down to the earth; on it, his repentance was accepted; on it, he died; and on it, the Hour will be established. And it is, with Allah, the Day of Increase. Likewise, the angels in the heaven name it, and it is the day of looking upon Allah, the Exalted, in Paradise." And in the report: "Indeed, for Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, in every Friday are six hundred thousand freed from the Fire." And in the hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, that He, peace be upon him, said: "If Friday is safe, the days are safe." And He, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed..."

As for his saying: Indeed, wealth is an attribute of the Truth (Al-Haqq), some shaykhs answered him by saying: Do you see that Allah the Exalted is rich (Ghani) through causes and accidents? And Ibn 'Ata' also cited as evidence when asked about that, saying: The rich person is better because he is described as truthful, but his first evidence is questionable, because the report has come detailed in a way that indicates the opposite: that the reward of the poor person in glorification increases over the reward of the rich person, and that their attainment of that reward is the favor of Allah (Fadl Allah) which He gives to whom He wills, for Yazid bin Aslam narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The poor sent me as a messenger to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and I said: I am the messenger of the poor to you; he said: "Welcome to you and to those from whom you have come, a people whom I love." He said: They said: O Messenger of Allah, the rich have taken away the good deeds by performing Hajj which we cannot afford, and performing Umrah which we cannot afford, and when they fall ill, they send ahead the surplus of their wealth as a provision for them; so the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Convey from me to the poor that for those among you who are patient and seek reward, there are three qualities not for the rich: As for one quality: Indeed in Paradise there are chambers that the people of Paradise look at as the people of earth look at the stars of the sky, none enters them except a poor prophet, or a poor martyr, or a poor believer. The second: The poor enter Paradise before the rich by half a day, which is five hundred years. The third: Glory be to Allah (Subhan Allah) and praise be to Allah (Alhamdulillah) and there is no god but Allah (La ilaha illa Allah) and Allah is the greatest (Allahu Akbar), and if a poor person says the like of that, the rich cannot catch up to the poor even if he spends ten thousand dirhams in it, and likewise all righteous deeds." And Allah the Mighty and Majestic has named knowledge (Ilm) as bounty (Fadl) in places. He said: 'And taught you what you did not know, and ever has the bounty (Fadl) of Allah upon you been great' {} And He said: 'And We gave David from Us bounty (Fadl)' {} meaning knowledge (Ilm). As for the reports (Akhbar), the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'From the sins are sins that are not expiated except by the anxiety (Al-Hamm) in seeking livelihood (Al-Ma'ishah).' The hadith 'From the sins are sins that are not expiated except by the anxiety in seeking livelihood' was previously mentioned in marriage. And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The truthful merchant (Al-Tajir Al-Saduq) will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection with the truthful ones (Al-Siddiqin) and the martyrs (Al-Shuhada).' The hadith 'The truthful merchant will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection with the truthful ones and the martyrs' was reported by Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim from the narration of Abu Sa'id. Al-Tirmidhi said it is good (Hasan), and Al-Hakim said it is from the mursal narrations of Al-Hasan. Ibn Majah and Al-Hakim have something similar from the narration of Ibn Umar. And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Whoever seeks the worldly life (Al-Dunya) lawfully (Halan) and with abstinence (Ta'affuf) from begging, striving (Sa'yan) for his dependents, and compassion (Ta'atuf) for his neighbor, will meet Allah with his face like the moon on the night of the full moon.' The hadith 'Whoever seeks the worldly life lawfully and with abstinence from begging and striving for his dependents' was reported by Abu Al-Shaykh in the book of reward, Abu Nu'aym in Al-Hilyah, and Al-Bayhaqi in the branches of faith from the narration of Abu Hurairah with a weak chain.
